I was completely burnt out working there, the environment is toxic and the amount of work expected is ridiculous. The job was not as advertised.

job_title: Applications Support Analyst in Peterborough, England
pros:
A major charity for the blind and partially sighted community.
Innovative thinking from the people on the ground.
Dedication from the staff base
Generally good salaries and benefits for the charity sector.
cons:
Poor leadership from the senior managers.
Too much "empire building".
Weak mid-level management and a tendency toward "jobs for the boys!"
Over-reliance on expensive/ineffective contractors as no faith in dedicated staff.
Human Resources dedicated to protecting the company reputation rather than protecting their biggest asset - their staff!
Lack of forethought when planning restructures and redundancies.

pros:
This review relates solely to RNIB Business (known internally as Solutions)
The organisation has a clear mission statement, "Making every day better for everyone affected by sight loss" underpinned by a set of values - Collaborative, Creative, Inclusive, Open - with a defined Group Strategy and 5 Year Plan 2014-2019.
Opportunity to educate the business community on accessibility issues enabling their business to develop by removing barriers to pan-disability issues.
Individual business units had committed, capable and knowledgeable staff with a desire to deliver the strategy and a willingness to overcome challenges.
Flexible working.
Generous holiday entitlement.
cons:
Poorly planned and executed induction to the organisation and the product/service portfolio.
Inability to define and communicate strategic plan down to a business unit level.
Lack of transparency, openness and empowerment with an over emphasis on verbal communication that can be disputed later.
Collaborative working prevented.
Sales targets poorly communicated and unachievable.
Use and comprehensive reporting ability of the CRM system ignored.
Management reports manipulated inflating achieved income figures creating future issues. 
Rudimentary KPIs demotivating staff. 
Appears to be a lack of cost control relating to capital assets and cost of sales.
No rationale behind portfolio development and operational requirement.

review_title: Staff morale at rock bottom after constant restructures
pros:
- Dedicated, passionate staff who care deeply about their customers and the services they provide, and are great colleagues to work alongside
- Being part of a meaningful cause 
- Internal comms between different areas is much improved especially with the internal social media
cons:
- Near-constant organisational change and repeated restructures over the last year have utterly crushed staff morale and many teams still have high uncertainty over their future
- Working atmosphere in the London office has become really miserable as a result of low morale and gradual devaluing of staff benefits
- Lack of communication and transparency from management and senior management
- Changes have resulted in the loss of so many highly talented and experienced employees
- Many areas are stifled by micro-management and rigid hierarchy
- Lack of meaningful training and opportunities for development or career progression
- Cutting expenditure has been prioritised at the expense of the services delivered to customers and staff retention and morale
- Organisation feels like it's currently lacking direction, values and integrity

job_title: Liaison Officer in Eccles, North West England, England
pros: Excellent staff was able to work well as a team
cons: Nothing bad about the job

review_title: A wonderful past, but a dismal future
pros:
Great staff spirit despite all that has happened to them over the last few years.
Genuine people doing great work to benefit blind & partially sighted people, on the front line
cons:
Dismal senior management who are too busy empire building and massaging their own egos, to see the damage they doing to the organisation.
Zero valuing of the staff, their feelings or their opinions.
They pay vast amounts of money to incompetent consultants who promise the impossible and because of their cost, they are believed!  After they don't deliver, they ride off into the sunset, pockets bulging with cash leaving chaos behind them.
So much of the money donated by the public is wasted.

pros: Lovely, hard working colleagues. Good pay. Provides excellent services to people with sight loss.
cons: Very poor employer - badly organised, lack of strategic planning in some areas, bullying common, stress and anxiety high, low staff morale, bizarre pay grades where some people are paid way too much, small minority of staff doing very little and getting away with it, or struggling in 'non-jobs.'

review_title: No respect, No transparency. A once great organisation run in to the ground
pros:
Talented and creative staff on the ground who care about bringing about innovative opportunities for engagement.  Always having Blind and partially sighted people at the forefront of their work.
Chair is intelligent and holds up the charity.
Good learning and development team who create opportunities for staff outside of their role.
Senior management have some good ideas but employee the wrong managers to deliver.
cons:
-Staff morale nearing zero, mental health of staff ignored. A once happy supportive environment turned in to a toxic wasteland.

HR - hard nosed, unreliable, unsupportive. Constant changing HR staff who  do not follow correct protocol.

Management - many bully staff and do not meet the basic requirements of their role. Many lack any direction and focus. 

Disengagement from the organisations core customers and values.

Constant restructures with little forethought.

Senior management often unaware or do not care about what is going on below them.

Little carer progression and little chance of a pay rise.

pros:
- Dedicated exec and senior leadership team committed to the future of RNIB for its customers and staff
- Good benefits and salary levels, one of the reasons I applied for my role at RNIB
cons:
- Change does come at a cost to staff morale but not their commitment to the charity and the work that we do 
- The atmosphere at the Head Office in London is improving but more could be done to make the environment more comfortable (wish list includes more places to relax at lunchtimes with cleaner kitchens and more comfortable seating areas, access to more cutlery, plates and cups, more pods for informal meetings to take place across the building, a more inviting reception area for visitors and for the RNIB Connect Radio to be played in the waiting area and café. Perhaps a lick of paint wouldn't go amiss if we can get a Corporate sponsor?)

pros:
There is a very friendly and helpful atmosphere. there have been a number of changes over the last year but we have now reached a moment of stability and there is a feeling that we are now building on what we had. There is a will to change and take things ot the next level across the organization. So if you have fresh ideas and the drive to put them into practice this is a place where you can make your mark very quickly. 
Management gives us a good level of autonomy and are very supportive. I have the freedom to implement my ideas. 
My colleagues are amazing and we really have a great time,
cons: Some systems and IT are a bit dated so some processes can be very manual. Change is under way but it's taking a bit of time.

review_title: Disappointing experiance from a national charity. The poor recent restructure means talented people are leaving.
pros:
Makes a difference to blind peoples lives
New CEO has potential to make real change
cons:
Decisions made by the few people deemed 'influencial' are poor,
Poor decision making in general,
Old fashioned approaches,
Don't value or motivate their staff,
People creating their own jobs as part of restructures,
Consultation 'lip service' only.

pros: There are some people in the organisation that work tirelessly to improve the lives of blind and partially sighted people.
cons: The organisation decided to hold a restructure with clearly no proper thought process on the feasibility of implementation or regard for staff and how it would affect them. This made a lot of staff feel vulnerable and uncertain. Strange/erratic team structures which vary across the charity meaning people in different departments with similar job tasks are on different pay bandings with no explanation. Double standards with regards to recruitment: hiring externally rather than promoting from within but then senior figures becoming annoyed that unsuccessful internal interviews want to/do move on. Zero career or skill development. Employing contractors on large salaries to do seemingly nothing. Zero cross-departmental understanding of 'what the other does' which meant things wouldn't get done, which only affects the people who matter most: blind and partially sighted people.

review_title: Poorly managed and wastes a lot of funds
pros: Friendly team - the majority of staff were driven by a passion for helping blind people. But let down by senior management
cons: Incredibly bad management - leading to huge wastage of funds. For example a fundraising campaign that drew in virtually no funds - went on for around 4 years - with a team of 4 people and budgets for events and advertising. I would estimate hundreds of thousands were spent - yet tens of thousands of money came in. Management refused to recognise the event was not working.  They also employed incredibly incompetent staff - staff that had affairs with their juniors, staff that bullied people and had to leave.

pros: On the ground employees are dedicated and work very hard. Unfortunately this not respected by management, particularly at the London Head office, who believe they are the only ones that keep the charity running.
cons: Everything! Awful atmosphere in head office...managers who are so disengaged from their employees that they lock themselves away in their ivory offices every day.  If only the donors for this charity knew directors use their donations to book taxis around London when they could get the tube and first class train tickets when they could go standard! The management have been lifted so high they can do nothing wrong and believe their own hype.  Sadly this will be the charities downfall.

pros:
Working for an amazing and important cause; work you can be proud of.
Dedicated, kind, fun, interesting colleagues who always pitch in and help everyone out.
cons:
Stagnant trustee board and weak leadership.
Too much work for number of staff, and so much if it could be streamlined if leadership was clearer and projects better managed.
Never enough money for raises, reward & recognition or learning & development.

review_title: Great organisation going through a period of renewal
pros: Like a lot of charities the organisation has gone through significant periods of change and is in a much better place as a result of the changes in senior leadership, new approaches and new skills added by more recent joiners.
cons: Change takes time and it can be challenging, but not really a con as it was something I found positive and the urgency to improve should be seen as a good thing.

pros: Central London office location - kings cross
cons:
Too many managers. Managers minding just 1 employee or bizzarely none.
Waste of public funds, not to mention I was bullied working here. 
Try other eye health charities, this one is a big NO

job_title: Team Administrator in Redhill, South East England, England
pros: Loved the people, the residents and staff alike. Only leaving because a job presented itself in my chosen career and my current role wouldn't allow for this opportunity
cons: Not very organised sometimes, not great communication (but this is being improved upon)

review_title: Not perfect, but working hard to change
pros:
Acute awareness of past failings
A dedicated team of professional staff 
A real sense of momentum 
A growing appreciation of the importance of planning
Cross-department working is great and happens naturally
cons:
Change is the only constant - not everyone appreciates this
Sometimes feel that there is more going on that we can manage

pros: Ability to utilise skill base in the knowledge that many many others will benefit through effort.
cons: Currently out of touch with a lot of the "real world" This is being addressed

pros: Good work life balance, social gatherings, flexible working, relaxed open plan working environment, best staff I have ever worked with.
cons: Shoddy management, too many internal changes causing job instability, average salaries, no personal development, stagnant roles, can be cliquey and gossipy.

review_title: Not a place to work unless you wish to volunteer
pros: Many of the London office departments have the feel of stepping into a monastery - no one talks to each other, which may be due to the fear running throughout the place.  However, if you look hard, a small number of hospitable and amiable members of staff can be found in the London offices
cons: The company's aim is to focus on visually impaired clients.  However, they treat their regular staff, upon whom the company could not function without, appallingly!  Like many UK companies today there is a 'robbing Peter to pay Paul' mentality. Pay below the level of Band M3 is dire, whilst those from Director level up are handsomely paid in comparison.  To add to the ridiculousness of it there is a 'developing' and 'competent' level within each Band.  The way that appraisals are run means that even Jesus Christ would not gain 'outstanding' and please note that the aim is to ensure that 'outstanding' is never attained! That would mean an increase in performance related pay.  In contrast the Directors are doing each others appraisals. That's more money in their pockets! I came into this organisation in the belief that I might be able to retire from the RNIB when the time came.  However, 'restructuring' the buzz word of the moment, has seen a number of people close to retirement being made redundant, at at time in their lives when the chances of future employment are close to nil.  Thanks to the 'Olympic Legacy' there is a move towards volunteering.  What this means is that paid workers are slowly being replaced by volunteers regionally. The irony here is that many of these volunteers are seeking full-time paid work within the organisation. Many sections are headed by Interims, who are not only earning vast sums in comparison to everyday staff, but their agencies are also earning vast sums.  These interims are making decisions about the RNIB that they will not be there to 'suffer' from.  Finally, there are not enough visually impaired or ethnic staff at the higher levels, especially at Director level, which is a travesty.

review_title: Charity has gone through some hard times but has transformed with a refreshed brand and a clear mission
job_title: Innovation and Technology Manager in Peterborough, England
pros:
Staff passion for the cause.
New senior management team with energy and focus.
cons:
Some staff still shell-shocked from a number of turbulent years. 
Reduction of benefits (much poorer Pension scheme, poor prospects of salary increases)

review_title: A charity that has lost its way
pros: Great people in my team and overall friendly atmosphere
cons: Management appear to be out of touch with the mission statement of the charity. This is an organisation which aims to support blind and partially sighted people. It is my belief that constant and ineffective internal restructuring has hampered this.

job_title: Human Resources Generalist in London, England
pros: The friendly people, the mission and values all make for a great place to work.
cons: The change which is needed can be hard going as a member of staff however the new CEO is really engaging and open which helps.

review_title: A fantastic organisation providing an essential service.
pros: A distinguished institution with a great focus on person-centred care. I enjoyed working with a helpful and collaborative team.
cons: A long commute proved to be too expensive for me.

review_title: Overall good charity to work for

Good team spirit.
Opportunities to learn and grow.
Great charitable work.
cons:
Diversity lacking in some areas and little focus on cross sectional diversity. 
Sense of 'if your face fits' in some teams. 
Few progression opportunities in some teams.

pros: We do great work for the visually impaired community, I also believe that being lead by workers that have visual impairments helps us be customer lead which is important to our service users.
cons: NAV financial system has been difficult to navigate and has had some teething problems.

pros: Passion from the front line CEO SLT driving change but VIPs still excluded from some areas
cons: Silo mentality them and us between certain teams.  Financially can't progress in all areas

pros: Committed and sincere staff on the frontline
cons:
Too many managers for too few operational posts.
Constant re-structuring de-motivating staff and taking up time and resources that would be better used for RNIB's services.
Cliques controlling recruitment and redundancy decisions.
Too much emphasis on academic projects at the expense of services.

pros: The overall service give to the young people is good.
cons: There is subtle racism within the work environment. Particular staff treat others differently and one feels not part of the team. When staff were conversing together, I would be there but overlooked as if the certain staff were 'looking through me'!!

review_title: Very laid back but lackluster salaries and limited progression
pros: Friendly management and co-workers, very little stress, marginal workload, great work-life balance, flexibility in working patterns.
cons: Very little progression, almost impossible to get a pay rise without promotion, can be chaotic and disorganized

pros: some supportive colleagues, walking guide dogs for colleagues.
cons:
lack of flexible working, micro management, high turnover (including CEO), high bonuses for the people at the top, lack of progression, dreadful pay, useless hr department, outdated office space, severe lack of accessibility despite being a blind and partially sighted charity, clueless managers, wasteful with resources and money, running a canteen infested with cockroaches, broken equipment

Would not recommend, stay clear

pros: You get to help people with sigh loss and make a real difference to peoples lives.
cons: There is over management with the entire company wasting resources as well as a lack of accountability.

pros: Pay was quite good !some good benefits provided too!People who I worked with did care about helping visually impaired
cons: Didn’t seem organised , I think some money was wasted especially down south

review_title: Continues to support in a challenging environment
pros: Trying to support blind and partially sighted people in a very competitive market
cons: Been a lot of change which develops an uncertain place to work

pros: Talented mid level employees who are dedicated to the cause.
cons: Clueless senior management at head / director level who aren't looking out for the customers or their staff. Money wastage is shameful.
